In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

In Julia, you can use the Dates library to work with date-time objects. Here's how you would write your function:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map((dt)->Dates.format(dt, "yyyyMM"), df[:dt])
end
```

This function takes a dataframe as input and adds a new column `ym` to it. The `map()` function applies the anonymous function (denoted by `(dt)->Dates.format(dt, "yyyyMM")`) to each element in the column `:dt`, which converts each date-time object into a string in the format `"yyyyMM"`.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
df = DataFrame(dt=DateTime[]) # initialize an empty dataframe with dt column
# add some dates to df...
add_yearmonth(df) # add ym column to df
```
